(35) The Buddha spoke a sÅ«tra for his disciples. At that time, a hunter was carrying a crossbow and
carrying over ten dead birds, passing by to observe the Buddha. His mind was focused, wishing to hear the sÅ«tra and listen to it. The Buddha then stopped and did not speak it for him.
The hunter withdrew and said:
If I become a Buddha, I will certainly universally explain the Way for people, without any opposition.
Ä€nanda asked the Buddha:
This person wishes to listen to the scriptures, so why did you go against him?
The Buddha said:
This person is a great bodhisattva, with a deeply solid mind.
In the past, he was a king. His mind was not impartial towards the many concubines. Those who were not favored conspired to poison the king to death.
The king was reborn in a hunter's family. The many concubines all fell into the realms of birds and beasts. Now they have finished their offenses and will later attain accomplishment.
If I were to explain the sutras to him, fearing that his mind would be frightened and fall into the path of arhats, I would not explain them to him.
Once, in a Buddhist temple, there was a golden cauldron used to cook the five flavors to provide for the monks.
At that time, there was an ordinary person who entered the temple and saw the golden cauldron. He wanted to steal it but had no means. He pretended to be a monk and entered the assembly of monks.
He heard the senior monk discussing the sutras, explaining the various merits and demerits, the essentials of birth and death, and the inevitable karmic retribution.
The thief's mind was enlightened, and he felt ashamed and remorseful. When he focused his mind, he saw the path of the arhat.
He thought about the reason. The cauldron was his teacher. He specially bowed to the cauldron three times and told the assembly of monks his story.
The enlightenment of all is due to their respective causes. Those who focus their minds single-mindedly will all see the truth.
37. Once in the past, Aniruddha had already attained arhatship, and among the assembly of monks, his appearance was upright and somewhat resembled a woman.

At that time, he was walking alone in the grass, and a young man of frivolous nature saw him and took him to be a woman. With licentious thoughts, he wanted to violate him, but when he realized he was a man, he saw his own body had transformed into a woman. Feeling ashamed and deeply resentful, he let himself go deep into the mountains and did not dare return for several years.
His family, wife, and children did not know where he was and thought he had died. They grieved and wailed without respite.
Aniruddha went to beg for alms and arrived at his house. The woman wept and told him that her husband had not returned, begging for the power of blessings so that they could make a living.

Aniruddha remained silent and did not respond, but in his heart he felt pity. He went to the mountains to seek him out and meet with him. This man then repented and blamed himself, and his body returned to that of a man. He was finally able to return home, and the family members saw each other.
Those who attain the Way cannot be treated with evil, otherwise they will suffer retribution.
(38) In the past, there was a monk who sat in meditation under a tree in a secluded place.
A monkey in the tree saw the monk eating, came down to his side, and the monk gave him the remaining food. After the monkey ate, he went to fetch water to provide for washing.
This went on for months.
One day, the monk suddenly forgot to leave food for the monkey when he ate. The monkey became very angry, took the monk's robe, and tore it all to shreds in the tree.
The monk became enraged at the animal and struck it with a stick, accidentally hitting and killing it.
Several monkeys came and made a commotion, carrying the dead monkey to a Buddhist temple.
The monks knew there must be a reason, so they gathered all the monks and questioned the monk about it. The monk explained the truth of the matter.
Then, they made a rule:
From today onwards, when the bhiká¹£us eat, they should always leave some for the sake of the wriggling creatures. They should not eat until they are full.
This is the beginning of the practice of giving alms by the donors.
(39) In the past, there was a turtle that encountered a severe drought. The lakes and marshes dried up, and it could not reach a place where it could find food.

At that time, there was a large crane that gathered and stayed by its side. The turtle begged for help, saying: Please save me. The crane pecked at it and carried it in its beak, flying over the capital city.
The turtle did not keep silent, and asked: What is this?
It did not stop, and the crane then responded to it. As the crane responded, its mouth opened, and the turtle fell to the ground. People got it and cut it up to eat it.
A foolish and stubborn person who does not guard their mouth and tongue is like this.
In the past, there was a Å›ramaá¹‡a who ordered an ordinary person to shave their head. After shaving, they bowed their head to the ground and said:
I wish that in my future lives, my mind and thoughts will be pure and my wisdom will be like that of a practitioner.
The practitioner said:
May you attain wisdom surpassing mine.
The man bowed and left.

Later, when his life ended, he was reborn in the Heaven of the Thirty-three. After his life in heaven ended, he was reborn in a great family as a son. Later, he became an ascetic, attained wisdom, and saw the path. This was due to his utmost sincerity.
(40) Once there was a brahman who begged from the king. The king wanted to go hunting and told the brahman to stay in the palace and wait for him to return.
He went hunting and chasing after animals, he lost his ministers and attendants. He reached a mountain valley and encountered a ghost who wanted to eat him. The king said:
Listen to me.
This morning at the city gate, I encountered an ascetic who begged from me. I said:
'Stay in the palace and wait for me to return.'
Now I beg to return briefly, give the ascetic what he wants, and then come to you to be eaten.
The ghost said:
I want to eat you now, how can you be willing to come back?
The king said:
Excellent! Indeed, there is no one more trustworthy. Should I remember this monk?
The ghost then released the king. The king returned to the palace, gave offerings to the monk, entrusted the country to the prince, and returned to the ghost.
When the ghost saw the king coming, moved by his utmost sincerity, he bowed in apology and did not dare to eat.
The teacher said:
The king, with a single sincerity, saved his life and the country. How much more so for the wise ones who uphold the five precepts?
Generous giving with utmost sincerity, its blessings are immeasurable.
(41) In the past, King Asoka always enjoyed giving alms and feeding ascetics. He ordered the prince to personally serve the offerings. The prince silently became angry and said:
When I become king, I will kill all the ascetics.
The ascetic knew that the prince was angry and said to the prince:
I will not be in this world for long.
The prince was startled and said:
The ascetic is so wise, he knows my thoughts.
He then thought in reverse:
When I become king, I will make offerings to the monks that surpass my father's.
His mind became harmonious and he turned away from evil and towards goodness.
The monk said:
By the time you become king, I will have already been reborn in the heavens.
The prince said:
How holy, O monk!
Later, when he became king, he used the five precepts and ten wholesome deeds as the governance of the country, and the country became prosperous and peaceful.

(42) In the past, a man of the four castes took two wives. The elder wife offered delicious food to the monks every day. The monks went to get the food every day. The younger wife was jealous of them.
The next day, when the monk came again, the younger wife went out to get the bowl and put impurities in it. She then put rice on top and handed it back to the monk.
The monk took it away. In the mountains, just about to eat, he saw the impurities and washed the bowl. He then did not dare to go again.

The woman's mouth and body both smelled foul, and people avoided her. After her life ended, she fell into the boiling excrement hell. In this way, she transmigrated through the three evil paths for many thousands of years. When her offenses were exhausted, she was reborn as a human, but she constantly craved to eat excrement and could not obtain it, and her stomach ached with pain.
Later, she became a married woman, and at night she would get up and steal to eat excrement.
This happened many times. Her husband became suspicious and went to investigate. He saw his wife eating excrement.
This was caused by her past karma.
There are four things that are difficult to accomplish for a person:
First, building a stupa; second, building a monastery for the saá¹ƒgha; third, offering food to the bhiká¹£u saá¹ƒgha; fourth, leaving home to become a Å›ramaá¹‡a.
These four things, once established, their blessings are immeasurable.
Why is this?
In the three realms, there are times when the ears are available.

Having already become a human, and further having wealth and property, one is able to uproot the roots of stinginess and greed, and immediately practice generosity. If one's meritorious deeds are pure and established, this is also difficult to attain.
Who can know this merit?
Only the Buddha.
The Buddha said:
Monks, do not consider those who invite each other for meals as close friends, but consider those who teach and admonish each other through the scriptures as close friends.

Monks, if you invite each other for delicious food and offerings, you will gain a good reputation in the world as monks, but in the next life you will not be worthy, and you will receive bad criticism from the Buddha.
Why is this?
Outsiders will see the monks and say:
'The Buddha's disciples only invite each other for delicious meals and fine robes. Who taught this?
It is the Buddha.
' They will receive bad criticism from the Buddha.
Monks, if you invite each other to the path of the scriptures and precepts, that is a great close friendship.
Why is this?
Outsiders will see the monks and say:
'The Buddha's disciples only invite each other to the scriptures, precepts, and the path. They do not give anything else to each other.'
The bhiká¹£us will gain a good reputation in this world and attain liberation in the next world, and they will have good discussions with the Buddha.
Why do I say this?

The Buddha is the teacher of the bhiká¹£us, and he teaches his disciples only through the scriptures and the path. Therefore, they do not necessarily benefit from food and drink, but only through the exchange of good words with each other.
The Buddha said:
Bhiká¹£us should know contentment. What is meant by knowing contentment?
It means seeking only one robe and one meal, always practicing walking meditation and not thinking of external pursuits, being able to stop and not disturb the mind, this is knowing contentment.

One should not consider the scriptures and precepts as contentment, nor the attainment of the four dhyÄnas and the four formless concentrations, nor the states of stream-enterer and once-returner as contentment.
This is what should not be considered as contentment.
(43) There was a bhiká¹£u who was begging for alms. He stopped on the road and suddenly lost control of his urine. People who saw this all ridiculed him, saying:
The Buddha's disciples have rules for walking and attire, but this bhiká¹£u stands and loses his urine, which is very laughable.
At that time, there was an outsider of the Nirgrantha Jains who saw people mocking this bhiká¹£u and immediately thought to himself:
We Nirgrantha Jains go naked without anyone asking questions;
the Buddha's disciples stand and urinate, yet people all laugh at them.
In this way, our teacher has no rules, so people do not laugh.
It is only because the Buddha's disciples' Dharma is pure and has propriety, making it easy to discuss.
He then took refuge in the Buddha and became a Å›ramaá¹‡a, and immediately attained the fruit of stream-entry.

Bhiká¹£us are like the lion, the king of beasts. What a teacher says among people should be in accordance with the Dharma. When walking, sitting, or rising, one should have propriety. Setting an example for others, one should not belittle oneself. Belittling oneself and slandering the sages is shameful.
Indra, the king of the Heaven of the Thirty-three, and the Four Heavenly Kings, on the fifteenth day, three times observe the world, who observes the precepts?
Seeing those who observe the precepts, the gods are immediately delighted.
At that time, on the fifteenth day, Indra, the king of the Heaven of the Thirty-three, sitting in the main hall, thought to himself:
If people in the world observe the three fasts on the fifteenth day, they can attain my position after their life ends.
The gods around him were greatly surprised and said:
Only by observing the three fasts on the fifteenth day can one attain the position of Indra.
There was a bhiká¹£u who had already attained arhatship, and he knew what Indra was thinking. He said to the Buddha:
Can it really be as Indra says?
The Buddha said:
Indra's words cannot be trusted, as he speaks untruthfully.
Why is this?
Those who diligently observe the three fasts on the fifteenth day can attain liberation from the world, so why would they want Indra's position?
This is speaking untruthfully, and cannot be fully trusted.
Only the Buddha knows who can understand the blessings of the fast.
There was a great dragon in the ocean, and the dragon wanted to rain on JambudvÄ«pa, fearing that the land could not bear this water.
The dragon thought:
Since the land cannot bear my rain, I will just rain in the ocean myself.

The Buddha's disciples have great spiritual power and virtue, and they want to bestow it upon the ninety-six kinds of non-Buddhist paths, fearing that there will be none who can bear it, so the Buddha's disciples only bestow it upon each other, just as the dragon rains in the ocean itself.

Once there was a brahman who was 120 years old. He never married when he was young, had no lustful thoughts, lived in a deep mountain where there were no people, made a hut with reeds, used bracken as a mat, ate fruits and wild vegetables as food, and did not accumulate wealth.
The king betrothed him but he did not go, his mind was at peace and he did nothing.
In the mountains for several thousand years, he played with the birds and beasts every day. There were four beasts:
The first was a fox, the second a monkey, the third an otter, and the fourth a rabbit.
These four animals listened to the sutras and precepts at the place of the practitioner for a long time, and thus all the fruits and vegetables they ate were completely exhausted.
Later, the practitioner wanted to move them away, and these four animals were greatly distressed and unhappy, and discussed together, saying:
We should each go and seek offerings for the practitioner.
The monkey went to another mountain, picked sweet fruits, and offered them to the practitioner, wishing for him to stay.
The fox also transformed into a human, sought food, and obtained a bag of rice and flour, which it offered to the practitioner, which could provide a month's supply, and wished for him to stay.
The otter also entered the water, caught a large fish, offered it to the practitioner, provided a month's supply, and wished for him not to leave.
The rabbit thought to itself:
What can I use to make an offering to the practitioner?
It thought to itself:
I will only offer my own body.
He then went to fetch firewood to burn and make charcoal, and went to tell the ascetic:
Now I am the smallest and thinnest of the rabbits, I can invite you to enter the fire to be roasted, and use my body to feed the ascetic, which can provide a day's food.
The rabbit then threw itself into the fire, and the fire did not burn.
The ascetic saw the rabbit, was moved by its benevolence and righteousness, and felt pity for it, so he stopped and stayed.
The Buddha said:
The brahman at that time is Dipankara Buddha, the rabbit at that time is myself, the monkey is Shariputra, the fox is Ananda, and the otter is Maudgalyayana.

(46) In the past, there were five ascetics traveling together, and on the way they encountered rain and snow. They passed by a shrine and stayed there for the night. In the house there was an image of a ghost spirit, which was worshipped by the people of the country and officials.
The four people said:
It is very cold tonight, we can take this wooden man and burn him to cook with.
One person said:ğŸ”½This is not right.
This is what people worship, and we cannot destroy it.
So they left it and did not destroy it.
The ghosts in this room always ate people. They said to each other:
We should eat that one person. That one person is afraid of us, but the other four are evil and cannot be violated.
The one who dared not destroy the image heard the ghosts speaking at night, got up and called his companions:
Why don't you take and destroy this image to cook it?
So they took it and burned it. The man-eating ghosts then fled.
When a person studies the Way, they should always be firm in their mind and spirit, and should not be timid and weak, allowing ghosts and spirits to take advantage of them.

(47) In the past, there was a king who abandoned his country and became a monk. He contemplated deeply in the mountains, with a thatched hut and straw mats. He considered himself successful and laughed loudly, saying, How delightful!
A person on the side asked him:
You are happy. Now sitting alone in the mountains studying the Way, what joy is there?
The monk said:

When I was a king, I had many worries. I was afraid that neighboring kings would take away my country, that people would rob me of my wealth, or that people would covet my wealth. I was always afraid that my subordinates would covet my wealth and rebel against me.
Now that I have become a monk, no one covets my wealth. It is unspeakably pleasant. For this reason, I say it is pleasant.

(48) In the past, there was a king who greatly loved the Way and virtue. He was always circumambulating a pagoda a hundred times. Before he finished, the king of a neighboring country came to attack and wanted to take away his country. The ministers were greatly frightened and immediately went to report to the king, saying:
There are troops coming.
O Great King, please stop circumambulating the pagoda and return to make plans to repel the great enemy.
The king said:
Let the troops come. I will not stop.
His thoughts were as usual. Before he finished circumambulating the pagoda, the troops dispersed and left.
A person who has a single-minded concentration can accomplish anything.
In the past, there was a king who always passed by the Buddha to pay homage, not avoiding mud and rain. The ministers by his side complained to each other:
What is the king thinking to be so bothered?
The king heard this and ordered the ministers upon returning to the palace:
Go find the heads of a hundred animals and a human head, and bring them back.
The ministers said to the king:
We have prepared as ordered, and they are all sold in the market, but the human head is not sold.
The ministers said:
We have sold the heads of a hundred animals and they are all sold, but this human head is smelly and rotten, and no one wants to buy it.
The king said to the ministers by his side:
You do not understand.
The one who passed by the Buddha before and paid homage to the Buddha, you said:
'The king's thoughts are bothered.'

If you want to know my head, it is like this. A dead person's head is impure. You should seek blessings to attain rebirth in the heavens. You are foolish and do not know, but instead say it is troublesome?
The ministers said:
It is truly as the great king says.
They kowtowed and apologized:
We are foolish and incompetent.
Later, when the king went out again, the ministers all dismounted and bowed to the Buddha, because the king was the Dharma.
(50) Once there was a king who went out on a trip. Whenever he saw a Å›ramaá¹‡a, he would get down from his carriage and bow to the Å›ramaá¹‡a. The ascetic said:
Great king, stop, do not get down.
The king said:
I go up, not down.
The reason he said I go up, not down is that now he bows to the ascetic, and after his life ends, he will be reborn in the heavens. This is why he said I go up, not down.
Once there was a person who died. Later, his soul returned and caressed his old bones. A person beside him asked:
You have already died, why do you still use your hands to caress dry bones?
The soul said:

This was my old body. The body did not kill living beings, did not steal, did not engage in adultery, did not engage in slander, did not engage in harsh speech, did not engage in false speech, did not engage in frivolous speech, did not engage in jealousy, did not engage in anger, and was not deluded. After death, he was reborn in the heavens. His wishes were naturally blissful and limitless. Therefore, I cherish it.
Once in a foreign country, there was a Å›ramaá¹‡a who practiced the Way in the mountains. A ghost transformed into a headless person and came to the Å›ramaá¹‡a, saying:
Without the trouble of a headache, the eyes see colors, the ears hear sounds, the nose knows fragrances, and the mouth experiences flavors. Completely without a head, how wonderful!
The ghost then disappeared. He transformed again, this time with no body but only hands and feet. The monk said:
One without a body does not know pain or itchiness, and without the five internal organs, one does not know illness. How pleasant!
The ghost then disappeared and transformed again into a person with no hands or feet, turning a wheel on one side of a cart and coming to the monk. The monk said:
Very pleasant!
Without hands or feet, one cannot walk and take others' possessions. How pleasant!
The ghost said:
The monk guards the one mind without moving.
The ghost then transformed into a handsome man who came and placed his head at the monk's feet, saying:
The monk holds his intention firmly like this, but now the monk's studies will only be accomplished for a short time.
He placed his head at the monk's feet and respectfully left.
(53) Once, a monk was practicing in the mountains. His inner robe came undone and fell to the ground. He then looked around and slowly pulled up his robe.
The mountain spirit appeared and said to the monk:
There are no people here either. Why do you crawl around on the ground to pick up your robe?
The monk said:
The mountain spirit sees me, and I also see the sun, moon, and various gods above me. It is not appropriate to be naked.
Without shame, one is not a disciple of the Buddha.
(54) In the past, there were six people who became companions and fell into hell together, all in the same cauldron, wanting to speak of their original crimes.
One person said sha, two people said na, three people said te, four people said she, five people said gu, and six people said dharani.
The Buddha saw this and smiled. Maudgalyayana asked the Buddha:
Why did you smile?
The Buddha said:

There were six people who were companions, all fell into hell, together in one cauldron, each wanting to talk about their original sins, the boiling water surging and leaping, unable to speak again, each with one word and then turned down.
One person said 'sha', in the world sixty million years, in the hells is one day, when will it end?
The second person said 'na', there is no fixed time, and I do not know when I will be able to escape?
The third person said 'te', alas, alas, what is the use of engaging in business?
In this way, unable to control one's mind, taking the share of five families to make offerings to the Three Jewels, foolishly greedy and insatiable, what benefit is there in regretting now?
The fourth person said 'she', saying that engaging in business is also not sincere, my wealth belongs to others, or I will suffer pain.
The fifth person said 'gu', who can guarantee that after I leave the hells, I will not violate the precepts again, and attain rebirth in the heavens or among humans?

The sixth person said, Dharma means originally not being concerned with the mind, like a chariot driver who loses the way and enters a wrong path, breaking the chariot axle, regretting that there is nothing to be done.
In the past, the Buddha sent ÅšÄriputra to the west to the country of Vá¹›ji, to inquire about the Buddha's three matters:
Is the Buddha's body at ease?

Are the recipients making progress?
ÅšÄriputra then went to that country with the Buddha's majestic spiritual power and proclaimed this.

All are at ease.

At that time, that Buddha turned the irreversible wheel and taught the Dharma for the bodhisattvas of the seventh stage. When ÅšÄriputra heard it, he returned from that country, his appearance and radiance walking and stepping more excellent than usual.
The Buddha told ÅšÄriputra:
When you arrived there, why do you walk so strangely and joyfully like this?
ÅšÄriputra said to the Buddha:
It is like a poor family, a hungry and cold person who obtains a great precious treasure like Mount Sumeru. Would they not be overjoyed?
The Buddha said:
Very good!
ÅšÄriputra said:
When I arrived in that land, I heard that Buddha speak of the profound matters of the irreversible stage, and therefore I am overjoyed and cannot contain myself.
The Buddha said:
Excellent!
As you have said.
The Buddha told ÅšÄriputra:

It is like a wealthy elder, a great householder, who has treasures made entirely of pure gold and maá¹‡i jewels, but inside there are copper, iron, lead, and tin that are discarded outside in the filth. A poor person happily takes them and brings them home, saying, 'I have obtained a great deal of the elder's treasures.' Are they really the precious treasures of the wealthy elder?
He replied:
No, they are not.
The Buddha told ÅšÄriputra:

What you have heard is like this poor person. What that Buddha spoke is only about the ten abodes and those who are pure in the midst of the raised [ground]. What you have heard is not enough to speak of.
ÅšÄriputra then became sorrowful, saying, I thought I had obtained a treasure, but it turns out to be lead and tin.
When ÅšÄriputra spoke of this matter, countless people all gave rise to the intention of unsurpassed, impartial liberation, and countless people attained the stage of irreversibility.
(56) In the past, MahÄmaudgalyÄyana sat under a tree and tested his spiritual eye, seeing eight thousand buddha-lands. He thought to himself:
The vision of the TathÄgata is not as good as mine.
He walked like a lion to where the Buddha was.
The Buddha told MaudgalyÄyana:
You are of the Å›rÄvaka type. Why are you now walking like a lion?
MaudgalyÄyana said to the Buddha:
I myself have seen the eight directions and eight thousand buddha-lands, but the Buddha's vision is not like mine, so I take a lion's pace.
The Buddha said:
Excellent, MaudgalyÄyana!
Your vision is vast indeed.
The Buddha told MaudgalyÄyana:
It is like comparing the light of a lamp to a maá¹‡i jewel, the difference is very great.
The Buddha said:
What my eyes see is like the ten directions, each with ten Ganges river sands of buddha-lands, with each sand being a buddha-land, and I see all that is within them.

There are those who come down from Tuá¹£ita Heaven and enter their mother's womb, those who are born, those who leave home to study the Way, those who subdue MÄra, those who are encouraged by Åšakra and BrahmÄ, those who turn the Dharma wheel and expound the Dharma everywhere, those who wish to enter parinirvÄá¹‡a, and those who have already entered parinirvÄá¹‡a and cremate their relics. There are countless such beings, and I use my eyes to see them all.

The Buddha emitted light from the white tuft between his eyebrows, illuminating the upper regions. He emitted light from his body, illuminating the eight directions. He emitted light from the soles of his feet, illuminating the lower regions, each a hundred thousand realms. At that time, the realms in the ten directions shook in six ways. The great light was unobstructed.

At that time, MaudgalyÄyana, immediately in front of the Buddha, saw countless thousands of Ganges Rivers, boundless realms, and everything therein as described by the Buddha before. He said to the Buddha:
The ten Ganges Rivers of realms mentioned by the Buddha, are they now what the Buddha has manifested?
The Buddha told MaudgalyÄyana:
It is because you do not believe that I have spoken little. What I have manifested now is beyond calculation.
When MahÄmaudgalyÄyana heard this, his body collapsed to the ground like a great mountain crumbling. He raised his voice and wept loudly:

I remember and know that the Buddha has such merits. Now I am like this. How can I let my body enter the great hell, and see with my right side for more than a hundred kalpas without attaining arhatship?
MaudgalyÄyana then said:

All those in the assembly, the World-Honored One says that I am foremost in spiritual powers, but this is not enough to speak of. The merits I have accomplished are not equal to knowing this, let alone those who have not yet attained anything.
The practice of the mind should be aimed at the Buddha, do not follow me and turn into spoiled seeds.

Countless thousands of dragons, gods, and people in the assembly all gave rise to the intention of unsurpassed, impartial, and complete enlightenment. Those who gave rise to the great mind immediately attained irreversibility. Those who had already attained irreversibility all attained the stage of nonretrogression.

In the past, there was a dragon king named Vatapi, whose majestic spirit was vast and far-reaching, and he often caused disturbances. His temperament was hasty and violent, and he frequently committed unlawful acts. He often joined with dragons to create unlawful wind, rain, thunder, and hail, killing people, birds, and insects, accumulating countless times.
There were ten thousand Venerable Arhats who discussed among themselves:
If one kills a person, one will fall into hell for an eon. Even if one pays back the death penalty a hundred times, it is still not finished.

Now this dragon has been harming sentient beings, the number is immeasurable, and it continues without stopping. It is feared that it will be difficult to save. We should go together to admonish and stop it.
At that time, the Buddha knew this and praised, saying:
Excellent!

You have left home to seek the Way of No-affliction, wishing to save the lives of all in danger and distress, and to deliver those with offenses. It is extremely joyful, and this is repaying kindness.
At that time, the Arhats said to each other:
It is not enough to have ten thousand people go together.
Then each person went separately, but they were all harmed and could not proceed. They said to each other:
Although we went alone, we were unable to subdue and transform this dragon to make it change for the good. We should now join forces with ten thousand people and go together.
The dragon released wind, rain, thunder, hail, and lightning. The ten thousand people were frightened and did not know where to go. They were humiliated and returned in defeat.
Ä€nanda said to the Buddha:

This dragon has killed so many people and animals, its crimes are numerous and immeasurable. Now it has frightened ten thousand arhats with hail and rained on their robes as if they were drowning people. Its crimes are deep and great, beyond calculation.
